item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Charlotte Brontë
item.description: "But life is a battle: may we all be enabled to fight it well!" -- Charlotte Brontë

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Oscar Wilde
item.description: "We are all in the gutter, but some of us are looking at the stars." -- Oscar Wilde

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Allen Saunders
item.description: "Life is what happens to you while you're busy making other plans." -- Allen Saunders

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Javier Marías
item.description: "Es curioso cómo el pensamiento incurre en lo inverosímil, cómo se lo permite momentáneamente, cómo fantasea o se hace supersticioso para descansar un rato o encontrar alivio, cómo es capaz de negar los hechos y hacer que retroceda el tiempo, aunque sea un instante. Cómo se parece al sueño." -- Javier Marías

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Charlotte Brontë
item.description: "Take the matter as you find it ask no questions, utter no remonstrances; it is your best wisdom. You expected bread and you have got a stone: break your teeth on it, and don't shriek because the nerves are martyrised; do not doubt that your mental stomach - if you have such a thing - is strong as an ostrich's; the stone will digest. You held out your hand for an egg, and fate put into it a scorpion. Show no consternation; close your fingers firmly upon the gift; let it sting through your palm. Never mind; in time, after your hand and arm have swelled and quivered long with torture, the squeezed scorpion will die, and you will have learned the great lesson how to endure without a sob." -- Charlotte Brontë

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Elizabeth Barrett Browning
item.description: "My patience has dreadful chilblains from standing so long on a monument." -- Elizabeth Barrett Browning

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Carmen Martín Gaite
item.description: "La rutina no está tanto en las cosas como en nuestra incapacidad para crear a cada momento un vínculo original con ellas, en nuestra tendencia a leerlas por la falsilla de lo rutinario, de lo ya aprendido. Hay que seguir dejando siempre abierta la puerta al cuarto de jugar." -- Carmen Martín Gaite

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Jonathan Safran Foer
item.description: "If there is no love in the world, we will make a new world, and we will give it walls, and we will furnish it with soft, red interiors, from the inside out, and give it a knocker that resonates like a diamond falling to a jeweller's felt so that we should never hear it. Love me, because love doesn't exist, and I have tried everything that does." -- Jonathan Safran Foer

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Virginia Woolf
item.description: "For it would seem - her case proved it - that we write, not with the fingers, but with the whole person. The nerve which controls the pen winds itself about every fibre of our being, threads the heart, pierces the liver." -- Virginia Woolf

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by John Milton
item.description: "The mind is its own place, and in itself can make a heaven of hell, a hell of heaven.." -- John Milton

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Emily Dickinson
item.description: "There is no Frigate like a Book To take us Lands away, Nor any Coursers like a Page Of prancing Poetry – This Traverse may the poorest take Without oppress of Toll – How frugal is the Chariot That bears a Human soul." -- Emily Dickinson

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Emily Dickinson
item.description:
"I'm nobody! Who are you? Are you nobody, too? Then there ’s a pair of us—don’t tell! They ’d banish us, you know.
How dreary to be somebody! How public, like a frog To tell your name the livelong day To an admiring bog!" -- Emily Dickinson

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Nancy Mitford
item.description: "Sun, silence, and happiness." -- Nancy Mitford

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Anne Fadiman
item.description: "One of the convenient things about literature is that, despite copyrights [...] a book belongs to the reader as well as to the writer." -- Anne Fadiman

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "What dreadful hot weather we have! It keeps me in a continual state of inelegance." -- Jane Austen

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Groucho Marx
item.description: "I've had a perfectly wonderful evening, but this wasn't it." -- Groucho Marx

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Helene Hanff
item.description: "I do love secondhand books that open to the page some previous owner read oftenest. The day Hazlitt came he opened to "I hate to read new books," and I hollered "Comrade!" to whoever owned it before me." -- Helene Hanff

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Kate Atkinson
item.description: "She should have done science, not spent all her time with her head in novels. Novels gave you a completely false idea about life, they told lies and they implied there were endings when in reality there were no endings, everything just went on and on and on." -- Kate Atkinson

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Kate Atkinson
item.description: "Oh, God. What was happening to her, she was turning into a normal person." -- Kate Atkinson

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Mary Ann Shaffer
item.description: "Perhaps there is some secret sort of homing instinct in books that brings them to their perfect readers. How delightful if that were true." -- Mary Ann Shaffer

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Mary Ann Shaffer
item.description: "Reading good books ruins you for enjoying bad books." -- Mary Ann Shaffer

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Betty Smith
item.description: "The world was hers for the reading." -- Betty Smith

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Betty Smith
item.description: "Yes, when I get big and have my own home, no plush chairs and lace curtains for me. And no rubber plants. I'll have a desk like this in my parlor and white walls and a clean green blotter every Saturday night and a row of shining yellow pencils always sharpened for writing and a golden-brown bowl with a flower or some leaves or berries always in it and books . . . books . . . books. . . ." -- Betty Smith

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Betty Smith
item.description: "Dear God," she prayed, "let me be something every minute of every hour of my life. Let me be gay; let me be sad. Let me be cold; let me be warm. Let me be hungry...have too much to eat. Let me be ragged or well dressed. Let me be sincere - be deceitful. Let me be truthful; let me be a liar. Let me be honorable and let me sin. Only let me be something every blessed minute. And when I sleep, let me dream all the time so that not one little piece of living is ever lost." -- Betty Smith

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Jerome K. Jerome
item.description: "It is impossible to enjoy idling thoroughly unless one has plenty of work to do. There is no fun in doing nothing when you have nothing to do. Wasting time is merely an occupation then, and a most exhausting one. Idleness, like kisses, to be sweet must be stolen." -- Jerome K. Jerome

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Jerome K. Jerome
item.description:
"I like idling when I ought not to be idling; not when it is the only thing I have to do. Thatis my pig-headed nature. The time when I like best to stand with my back to the fire, calculating how much I owe, is when my desk is heaped highest with letters that must be answered by the next post. When I like to dawdle longest over my dinner is when I have a heavy evening's work before me. And if, for some urgent reason, I ought to be up particularly early in the morning, it is then, more than at any other time, that I love to lie an extra half-hour in bed.
Ah! how delicious it is to turn over and go to sleep again: "just for five minutes." Is there any human being, I wonder, besides the hero of a Sunday-school "tale for boys," who ever gets up willingly?" -- Jerome K. Jerome

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Barbara Pym
item.description: "Perhaps there can be too much making of cups of tea, I thought, as I watched Miss Statham filling the heavy teapot. Did we really need a cup of tea? I even said as much to Miss Statham and she looked at me with a hurt, almost angry look, 'Do we need tea? she echoed. 'But Miss Lathbury...' She sounded puzzled and distressed and I began to realise that my question had struck at something deep and fundamental. It was the kind of question that starts a landslide in the mind. I mumbled something about making a joke and that of course one needed tea always, at every hour of the day or night." -- Barbara Pym

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Barbara Pym
item.description: "I stretched out my hand towards the little bookshelf where I kept cookery and devotional books, the most comfortable bedside reading." -- Barbara Pym

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Charlotte Brontë
item.description: "And who cares for imagination? Who does not think it a rather dangerous, senseless attribute, akin to weakness, perhaps partaking of frenzy - a disease rather than a gift of the mind? Probably all think it so but those who possess, or fancy they possess it. To hear them speak, you would believe that their hearts would be cold if that elixir did not flow about them, that their eyes would be dim if that flame did not refine their vision, that they would be lonely if this strange companion abandoned them. You would suppose that it imparted some glad hope to spring, some fine charm to summer, some tranquil joy to autumn, some consolation to winter, which you do not feel. All illusion, of course; but the fanatics cling to their dream, and would not give it for gold." -- Charlotte Brontë

item.title: 93bcn add a quote by Penelope Fitzgerald
item.description: "A good book is the precious life-blood of a master-spirit, embalmed and treasured up on purpose to a life beyond life, and as such it must surely be a necessary commodity." -- Penelope Fitzgerald
